subject: Data
title: The Filing Cabinet Problem
description: One-minute skill: The Filing Cabinet Problem.

hook.text: By the 1960s, corporations had rooms full of filing cabinets. Finding one customer record could take an hour.

buildup.text: Early computer storage mimicked physical files â€” flat files stored as sequential records on tape or disk.

discovery.text: The 'filing cabinet problem' was clear: data spread across departments with no cross-referencing or linking.

twist.text: Companies often had the same customer stored differently in accounting, shipping, and marketing â€” with conflicting data.

climax.text: This chaos of duplicated, inconsistent data drove the invention of database management systems.

punchline.text: Modern databases were born from the pain of messy filing cabinets.

quiz.question: What was the core 'filing cabinet problem' that databases solved?
options: Data was duplicated, inconsistent, and impossible to cross-reference
